But as soon as things go wrong, then finally the immigrants become a lot of misery. That's how it is in Spain. There is the cultural aspect of the church that has never been solved, well Franco solved it in his time, but not Spain. So, this cultural aspect of the church, when we talk about separating things, well, we will see the question of immigration with other eyes, as France does. But in Spain we have started to welcome immigrants, only a few years ago, with the obvious exception of South Americans. Obviously, it is the same language, so they were more easily welcomed. Now, Spain, it brings from Africa, they bring for Latin America, so, and everybody goes where they can go. Europe has always had open doors, when other countries elsewhere have not always been open like those of Europe and Spain is located in a place, obviously, that makes it receive many people who pass through, because afterwards they go to France, Belgium, Germany and this is a problem that we face. So even if it's a transit immigration, for a year or two or sometimes for a lifetime or sometimes it's not just a few days. So ultimately it's an economic issue. We don't talk about benefits today because things are bad. And if things were better, we could try to get into the debate. So we need to ask the economic question and better link it to this immigration question.

We also have a responsibility; I think that must also be clear; to humanity, I would say. We have to make sure, of course, that we maintain our standard of living, but we also have to find a way out. All people in the world have the right to eat, to feed themselves, to educate their children. I think we have enough possibilities here in Europe to deal with immigration, yes? And at the same time we have to make sure that the countries of origin of the immigrants can develop further; economically, but also culturally and socially. It is also a question of solidarity between continents, between countries. As I said, we should perhaps remember what Andalusia, my region, was like eight centuries ago. There was a lot of immigration, later also emigration - and I think that nobody leaves his home country for fun, but people do it out of need, because they have nothing left to survive. Hardly anything to eat. They don't necessarily do it voluntarily. So life has to be very bad, it has to be very bad for people to decide to leave their home country and that there is no prospect of improvement, that things cannot be improved in the short term in the country. I think we have to make sure that there is a greater balance between the different regions of the world. And I would also like to point out the following: Everyone has their own language and their own culture; these must also be respected and protected. I would also like to ensure that each individual is allowed to keep and cultivate his or her own language and culture. So you should make sure that everyone gets along, right? No matter what opinion we have of the other. Well, in today's time, back then, I was talking about the time 800 years ago. When, in my region of Andalusia, very different peoples, very different religions got along well with each other, that is, the Muslims, the Christians, the Jews, there was a great harmony, that has been lost. We have to try to get along with each other again, to understand each other, otherwise we won't achieve anything. And if we do not understand this situation, then we will not understand the 27 states that make up the European Union today. And only when we succeed in doing that, we will find a way out. Not necessarily in the capitals, that's how I see the problem of declining voter turnout, which is also due to the economic situation, but also to these social grievances. So if we want to achieve something, I think we have to find another way. Immigration is something we have to accept, it has to be legalized. We have to create precautions for it, find ways. In my region, too, there has been a lot of migration, emigration in particular, also to the Netherlands, to Germany, to many other European countries.

Und die eingewanderten Bauarbeiter, die also zu ganz niedrigen Löhnen ins Land geholt werden, das kann man nicht vergleichen mit Facharbeitern, denen man – ich glaube, wenn man denen etwas entsprechendes bieten würde, also nicht einen Vertrag über einige Jahre zu bestimmtem Lohn und dass er möglichst auch die Familie nachkommen lässt, dann bestehen gute Aussicht, dass er auch bleiben wird; und das gilt genauso für die Polen, die zu diesem Zweck ins Ausland gehen um zu arbeiten. cleaned_comment: Maybe you also have to take into consideration the immigration structure. Let's talk about legal immigration, so especially family reunion. So we're talking about children, wives, the family being reunited, I think that's a human right. So I would say that this was uncontested. As far as the qualification of training is concerned, every country can offer training to its citizens, to its potential citizens, but there has to be a will; it has to be known whether this will exists or not and whether integration is lived or not. It can work well, it can't work. There are some examples in Austria where it works very well, but there are other examples that completely fail [...]. So, highly qualified people can immigrate without any problem, there is a system that exists but it is also very, very difficult and there are quite important obstacles. We have to ask ourselves in general: Where are we going? Do we need immigrants, do we treat them respectfully, regardless of their background, or is it a political calculation, do we want to form an opinion against immigration in general? The media make me think that it is more like that; they really try to form an opinion against immigrants, even highly qualified ones, especially against human beings who simply need our help, so asylum seekers. And in Austria, the climate is such that we try to deny help to these people, which I find serious. And here I plead for an active intervention of the European Union in this field.
speech: [43 :47] Peut-être il faut également prendre en considération la structure de l’immigration. D’en parlons de l’immigration légale, donc surtout la réunion familiale. Donc on parle d’enfants, d’épouse, de la famille qui est réunifié, je pense que ça c’est un droit de l’homme. Donc ça je dirais que c’était incontesté. À ce qui concerne la qualification de formation, chaque pays peut offrir une formation à ses citoyens, à ses citoyens potentiels, mais il faut y avoir une volonté ; il faut savoir si cette volonté existe ou non et si on vit l’intégration ou non. Ça peut bien fonctionner, ça ne peut pas fonctionner. Il y a en Autriche quelques exemples ou cela fonctionne très bien mais il y a d’autres exemples qui foirent complètement [...]. Donc, des personnes hautement qualifiés peuvent immigrer sans problème, il y a un système qui existe mais ça aussi c’est très très difficile et il existe des obstacles assez importants. Il faut se poser la question en règle générale : Où va-t-on ? Donc est-ce qu’on a besoin des immigrés, est-ce qu’on les traite de manière respectueuse, indépendamment de leur formation ou est-ce que c’est un calcule politique, est-ce qu’on veut former de l’opinion contre l’immigration en générale. Les médias me font penser que c’est plutôt cela ; on essaye vraiment de former une opinion contre les immigrés, même hautement qualifié, surtout contres des personnes humains qui ont tout simplement besoin de notre aide, donc les chercheurs d’asile, les demandeurs d’asile. Et en Autriche justement, le climat est tel que nous essayons de refuser de l’aide à ces personnes, ce que je trouve grave. Et là, je plaide en faveur d’une intervention active de l’Union Européenne dans ce domaine. [45 :34]

cleaned_comment: Yes, in France, there has always been immigration. In the 20th century, there were in particular the Polish for a certain period of time, a little later the Italians, the Portuguese and the Spanish, before the Second World War. This did not pose any problems, in the sense that people came to France to work, not necessarily to die, at the end of their normal life. They came to work because there was more work in France at that time than in their country of origin. But they tried to assimilate, to integrate into the host country. And it was relatively easy because the cultures were relatively close. And from all that we have heard since the beginning, people are not opposed to immigration, but we feel that the problem that arises, even if the word has not been pronounced, is that many immigrants are of Muslim faith and that precisely, that makes a very different culture. So, it's true, it's a problem, we mustn't hide   [...] our faces. Most immigrants try to live like they do in their country of origin, others do not. But there is indeed a problem that many people feel every day and this problem, in fact, makes them against immigration in that sense. That's the first point. Second point, it is true that by accepting immigrants in the European Union, we somehow impoverish the countries of origin. And for that we can't do anything, it's not us who go and get them, it's them who come of their own free will and I don't see how to do it differently. But it is certain and even last night, I saw on French television a program about French doctors who had operated on children in Togo and the Togolese doctor said that there are more Togolese doctors from the Paris region than Togolese doctors in Togo themselves. But that is not our fault. It is a choice they make and I do not see how we can oppose it.

Au 20ième siècle, il y a eu particulier les polonais pour une certaine période, un peu plus tard les italiens, les portugais et les espagnols, avant la seconde guerre mondiale. Ça n’a pas posé des problèmes, dans se sens que les gens venaient en France pour travailler, pas obligatoirement pour y mourir, en fin de leur vie normale. C’était ils venaient travailler parce qu’il y avait plus de travail dans cette époque en France que dans leur pays d’origine. Mais ils essayaient de s’assimiler, de s’intégrer dans le pays d’accueil. Et c’était relativement facile parce que les cultures étaient quand même relativement proches. Et de tous ce qu’on a entendu depuis le début,  les gens ne sont pas opposés à l’immigration, mais on sent que le problème qui se pose, même si le mot n’a pas été prononcer, c’est que beaucoup d’immigrés sont de confession musulmane et que justement, ça fait une culture très différente. Alors, c’est vrai, c’est un problème, il ne faut pas se voiler [13 :10] [00 :00] […] la face. La plupart des immigrés essaie de vivre comme on vit dans le pays d’origine, d’autres ne le font pas. Mais il y a effectivement un problème et que beaucoup de gens ressentent tous les jours et se problème, en fait, fait qu’ils sont contre l’immigration au sens là. Ça c’est un premier point. Deuxième point, c’est vrai qu’en acceptant des immigrés dans l’Union Européenne, on appauvrit en quelque sort les pays d’origine. Et pour ça on y peut rien, ce n’est pas nous qui allons les chercher, c’est eux qui viennent de leur propre gré et je ne vois pas comment le faire différemment. I believe, as a predominantly European-oriented person, that the politicians must not make this problem, asylum law then above all, a marshalling yard, will have to make a certain unification. Die Sachlage ist die, diese Einwanderungs-/Zuwanderungspolitik, einschliesslich Asylpolitik sind zu 90 Prozent nationales, im Kernbereich der nationalen Politik. cleaned_comment: So, what I could understand when I worked in these two organizations, one of which was rather the reception of immigrants, the other rather in the control of immigration. What I understand is that today the states are still free to set their own rules for their own territory. These rules are more important than the rules set by the EU, which is more concerned with the movement of immigration within the borders. What I could see is that in France, for example, there was a period when people arriving in France were required to sign a contract that included learning the French language. To facilitate integration. Today we have radically changed our approach, that is to say that we ask that people who wish to immigrate to France be able to prove in their own country that they are French. So in fact there are movements of agents of the French state that are in countries that are identified as countries for seeing immigration applications and it is in these countries, when we control for example the language, so that is a first criterion but of course there is another criterion that was posed more recently by the French government which is to identify the professional skills. It's a little bit like the euro question, which effectively means choosing between [...] the immigration population, which is what we need in France today. But there is another phenomenon that is very important, which has been the subject of discussion but which at the same time is laid down as a basic principle by the Geneva Convention. It is the right to family reunification, the fact that a person who has arrived in France has the right to bring his family. So this right is laid down in the Convention on Human Rights. And this is a right that is currently unassailable and that is difficult to reconcile with migration policies in the framework that states would like to make of this migration policy. Here is the reading of what I could see and understand.
speech: [33 :25] Donc, ce que j’ai pu en comprendre quand j’ai travaillé dans ces deux organismes, dont l’un était plutôt l’accueil des immigrés, l’autre plutôt dans le control de l’immigration. Ce que je comprends c’est qu’aujourd’hui les états restent assez mettre de poser leurs propres règles sur par rapport à leur propre territoire. Ça reste des règles prépondérantes par rapport aux règles qui sont posés par l’UE, qu’elle chère plus des mouvements de l’immigration à l’intérieur des frontières. Ce que je pu en voir, c'est qu’on a eu par exemple en France la période ou on a posé à ce que les personnes qui arrivent en France signent un contrat qui prévoyait notamment d’apprendre la langue française. Pour pouvoir faciliter l’intégration. Aujourd’hui on a changé radicalement de tique, c'est-à-dire qu’en fait on demande a ce que les personnes qui souhaitent immigrer en France, soit déjà en mesure de prouver dans leur pays qu’elle sasse par les français. Donc en fait il y a des déplacements d’agents de l’état français qui ont êtes dans les pays qui sont identifiés comme des pays pour voyer demande d’immigration et c’est dans ces pays la, quand qu’on contrôle par exemple la langue, alors ça c'est un premier critère mais bien sur y a un autre critère que était posé plus récemment par le gouvernement français qui est d’identifier les compétences professionnels. Mais y a un autre phénomène qu’est très important, qui a été sujet à discussion mais qui en même temps est posé comme principe de base par la convention de Genève. C’est le droit regroupement familial, le fait qu’une personne quand elle est arrivée en France, elle a le droit de faire venir sa famille. Donc ce droit-là, il est posé au titre de la convention du droit de l’homme. Et ça c’est un droit pour l’instant inattaquable et qui se concilie difficilement avec les politiques de migration dans l’encadrement que voudraient faire les états de cette politique de migration. I have experienced this myself many times in my professional activity that we have people, for example, who have a university or college degree from Russia, who already have work experience in highly qualified professions. But in diplomas, qualifications are not recognized. This is the problem. And then we say we have doctors, we have a lot of people who come to us to work and quite qualified. So when we talk about the emigration of German doctors, all of a sudden we ask these doctors - some years ago, fifteen years ago, it was impossible, it was very very difficult for example to realize a transition year and to adapt to the medical system in Germany. Today it is different, the possibility exists. But in other professions, it is really extremely difficult to have a diploma recognized. And I don't think this is the right solution.
speech: [42 :31] En ce qui concerne ce point de vue, je voudrais donner mon opinion. À quoi sert une qualification, à quoi sert une formation si les diplômes ne sont pas reconnus ? J’ai vécu cela moi-même nombreuses fois dans le cadre de mon activité professionnelle que nous avons des personnes, par exemple qui ont un diplôme d’université ou d’école supérieure en provenance de Russie, qui ont déjà une expérience professionnelle dans des métiers très qualifiés. Mais dans des diplômes, les qualifications ne sont pas reconnus. C’est ça justement le problème. Et puis on dit nous avons des médecins, nous avons beaucoup des personnes qui viennent chez nous pour exercer une activité professionnelle et tout-à-fait qualifié. Alors quand on parle à l’émigration des médecins allemands, tout à coup on demande ces médecins – il y a quelques années, il y a quinze ans, c’était impossible, c’était très très difficile par exemple de réaliser une année de transition et de s’adapter au système médical en Allemagne. Aujourd’hui c’est différent, la possibilité existe. Mais dans d’autres professions, il est vraiment extrêmement difficile d’avoir une reconnaissance de diplôme. Et je ne pense pas que ce soit la bonne solution. [43 :42]
